Explaining these five chapters has both common and specific aspects.
Common means the same, specific means different.
These five chapters are used to explain all sutras, therefore they are called the same.
The explanation of the name is different, up to the classification of teachings which is different, therefore they are called specific.

Moreover, the common means shared;

In this way, the common and specific are focused on one part.
Commonly, it is explained together in seven parts; specifically, it is explained individually in five layers.
It is like the sharp and dull faculties, which require the two approaches of extensive and concise.
The common and specific teachings are not discussed here;

In the common interpretation, there are seven parts:
1. Stating the chapters;
2. Citing the evidence;
3. Arising;
4. Opening and combining;
5. Distinguishing;
6. Contemplating the mind;
7. Unifying the differences.
Stating the chapters makes it easy to remember and uphold, giving rise to the mind of mindfulness.
Citing the evidence based on the Buddha's words gives rise to the mind of faith.
Arising prevents confusion and gives rise to the mind of concentration.
Opening and combining, distinguishing, unifying differences, and so forth give rise to the mind of wisdom.
Contemplating the mind is hearing and practicing, giving rise to the mind of diligence.
The five minds establish the five faculties, eliminate the five hindrances, form the five powers, and enter the three gates of liberation.
The brief explanation of the seven layers has this general meaning.

As for extensively explaining the five chapters, each one extensively gives rise to the five minds and five faculties, causing them to open, reveal, understand, and enter the Buddha's knowledge and insight.
First, the five chapters are listed.
The listing of names has four parts:

As for establishing the name, the sage's original intention in establishing the name is to open up the profound and advance beginners, causing all to see and hear, to seek the path and go far, and reach the ultimate. Therefore, he uses names to name the Dharma and establish sentient beings.
As for distinguishing, the Dharma has coarse and subtle. If the three truths are separate, it is coarse Dharma;
If the three truths are perfectly integrated, it is subtle Dharma.
This subtle truth originally exists. The text says, This Dharma abides in the Dharma-position, and the characteristics of the world always abide.
Only I know this characteristic, and so do the Buddhas of the ten directions.
This is not something that even non-retreating bodhisattvas or those who have entered the realization of the two vehicles can know, let alone the various beings of humans and gods.
Although the Buddha knows this, he is not in a hurry to speak.
The text says, If I praise the Buddha vehicle, sentient beings will sink in suffering.
Because of slandering the Dharma and lack of faith, they will fall into the three evil paths.
Therefore, in the initial teaching, the fused and un-fused are established, and those of small capacity do not hear about it at all;
In the next teaching, the un-fused is established, and those of great capacity do not use it at all;
In the next teaching, both are established, using the fused to criticize the un-fused, causing those of small capacity to be ashamed of the un-fused and aspire to the fused;
In the next teaching, both are established, causing those of small capacity to rely on the fused to approach the un-fused, and those of great capacity to follow the un-fused and approach the fused.

Although various establishments are set up for sentient beings, they are all just words spoken according to the minds of others, not the original intention of the Buddha, so it is said that he is not in a hurry to speak.

Now this sutra is straightforward and abandons the unintegrated, only speaking of the integrated, causing those at a single seat to share the same flavor of the Way, thus expressing the fundamental aspiration of the Tathagata's appearance in the world. As for the analogy of the lotus flower, there are coarse and wonderful.

The lotus flower has many wonders:

For these various reasons, the lotus flower is used as an analogy for the wonderful Dharma.
